channel.title: Automation - The Car Company Tycoon Game
channel.description:
This game just got put on steam, like yesterday, and even in it's very early access it's awesome. Anyone here who's into building vehicles and motors, and playing sandbox games, this is something you'd enjoy.
[img]http://cloud-4.steamusercontent.com/ugc/38617858245764529/C529633F4CBC5833F038EECF15A4D58B56D9A8E2/[/img]
Built this big block which tested at 1500HP @ 5500RPM (graph to the left doesn't read properly unless the motor is actually running). it's really in depth. From choosing what material to make the heads out of, to the compression, to the exhaust system you get to design the whole motor and then throw it in a car you get to build yourself. (Vehicle builder isn't very in-depth, yet.). Anyways, they're adding a multiplayer mode, eventually, let me know if anyone gets it so we can try the multiplayer out, when released.

item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:18, topic:550548”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=669459.msg4476898#msg4476898 date=1426450438]
Hence why I don’t support it.
I don’t feel like supporting the idea of “risk taking” when it comes to buying a game.
I want what I’m promised. If I go to buy a car, I don’t want to sign for a 2015 Ferarri and then find out that they’re only giving me a 2010 Mustang.
[/quote]
It’s situational IMO. In it’s current state, I like the game, I could play the game for a long time. If you couldn’t play without the tycoon part, don’t buy it yet. Early access gives us a chance to almost “be a part” of the development even if the developers aren’t engaged with the players. If the game is still fun, and sometimes the early access price is lower, you get an advantage. DayZ was like $5 at some point wasn’t it? Granted it still sucks, but it’s a not a shitty $5 game, it’s a shitty $30 game. If you would have bought it at $5, you’d have the same game, with more content (and the same bugs, in this case).[/quote]
You are right, it does vary per game and development and etc.
But, when they’re selling an incomplete game at the price full games go for, that’s just ridiculous.
I understand that they’re probably selling it at/around full price because the people that get it will own the game even after EA is over, but the point of EA is for the players to help you, is it not? So why not give them a discount?
I could see them raising the price as features are added, even.
I.E: As the game stands now, it sells for $10. They add a new feature, like driving (just an example, i know it’s not a driving game), and then they raise the price to $15-$20. Or maybe they could raise it as they feel the content is less prone to bugs.

But if the game just barley came out and is selling for full price, and isn’t complete, I just don’t see how that’s appealing to anyone.
[hr]
Take a look at Besiege. That game is wildly popular. Like the internet exploded over it in a matter of days. The game is only $7 in Early Access. The game looks promising based on the community feedback overall, and they’re no where near done.
Do you really think they’re going to keep selling it at $7? Nope. But them selling it at such a low price makes more people inclined to try it because they won’t feel like it’s such a loss. I’d rather spend $7 on a game that never gets finished instead of $30.

item.title: Automation - The Car Company Tycoon Game
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:13, topic:550548”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=669459.msg4476716#msg4476716 date=1426339992]

I don’t fully agree on the point you two are making. In a specific case, Automation’s development team does kind of piss me off with their talk of money. They told a user on the steam forums that a in-game driving simulation would be far away, because it’s “expensive”… Doesn’t make much sense how adding a feature would cost money, but okay. That’s a form of donation/early-access abuse, not what it was meant for. Early access is a good model, only when used correctly. Allow people to purchase the early stages at a low price, then use that to gain feedback, add content, raise price toward final product asking price goal (if applicable), repeat.

You’re forgetting companies used to (and some still do…) pay people to do what you just described.
A lot of games (RuneScape, for one) offer free beta’s (However, RuneScape mostly does the beta for members only… which I only somewhat agree with) for people to give feedback and etc on.

Early access gives people an opportunity for people to buy the game early instead of waiting months for it to have a final release. Sure, companies pay people some times to test their games, but that’s entirely different. These users are paid to look for glitches and bugs exclusively alot of the time, early access alot of times is just so you can play the game, once it reaches a playable state.
[/quote]
And then you have to define what a “playable state” is.
Because, depending on what the final product of the game is, you could consider the first stages of the game not playable.
Like, lets take this car game you just bought. You said they have are working on adding the whole “tycoon” feature to run a manufacturing shop. Would it not make sense for them to release a copy of their game (Which the point of the game is to manage a manufacturing shop) with the manufacturing shop working? Or at least partially implemented.
As far as I see it, in the current state, all they gave you is a car builder. Not a tycoon game.
Sure, they may update it so it’s a tycoon game, but it technically isn’t one now as the feature isn’t there.
[hr]
Great example:
The moparscape server alpha/beta/w.e.

We were able to login and “play” the game. But at least 70% of the content wasn’t working (not complaining, just stating).
Would you consider that “playable”? because I wouldn’t. It’d be playable for the alpha/beta, but as a full game, no.[/quote]
You’re completely correct, right now it is only a car/engine builder.

Valve puts it very plain and simple, this is how early access works.

What I define as playable is pretty much the basic game loop in game development. Start, Logic, End. If the game starts, there’s an activity, and a way out, I consider that playable.
